concern:
What’s popping reddit

I’m 25 years old. And I just got my license to practice as a nurse. I’m pretty late because I got diagnosed with OCD and it absolutely turned my life around. It took a lot of work to finally get to the point of taking and passing the NCLEX, but we’re here. 

However, a huge, huge dream of mine, is to eventually practice as an Psych NP. 

I wanted to practice as a nurse for a year (as recommended) go to school full time, and be done within 2 years instead of 4. This trajectory would let me graduate at 29-31 years old. 

Getting my own place would make grad school difficult, no doubt. I’d have to cut hours in my job, pay my bills somehow, go to clinicals after work/do homework as well. It would just make life a lot harder

If I stayed, I wouldn’t have to pay rent. I could pay some chunks off my loans, go to school full time and work part time so I’d save cash. The stress of trying to survive and keep it all together wouldn’t be there, which leaves me more time to focus on school.

However, that’s a long time with my parents. Everywhere I see, everyone advocates moving out and getting your life together on your own. I really can’t help but feel like a loser. 

But at the same time, If I just stay an RN, I’m not making the money or living the life I want. I prob wouldn’t stay in the city I’m in and love and would move to somewhere more affordable. And this would be all for society accepting me for independence 

My dating life and social life would prob suffer due to judgment from being home as well. I just don’t know…

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! Welcome to our session today. I'm here to listen, support, and explore your thoughts and concerns with you in a safe and nonjudgmental space. Please feel free to share whatever is on your mind, and we'll work together to understand and navigate your experiences. What would you like to talk about today?
Hey, thanks for having me. I’m kinda torn about this big decision—whether to move out or stay with my parents while I work towards becoming a Psych NP.
It sounds like you're really weighing the pros and cons of each option. Can you tell me more about what's making this decision feel so complicated?

Yeah, it’s just a lot to balance, you know? I’m worried about the financial stress of moving out while juggling grad school, but staying home makes me feel like I’m not really adulting or living up to what people expect.

You feel like you're caught between two challenging situations: the financial strain of moving out and the emotional pressure of staying home. It sounds like you're worried about the financial impact of moving out while balancing your studies, but staying home also makes you feel like you're not quite meeting societal expectations of being an adult.
Yeah, exactly, it’s like I’m stuck between a rock and a hard place. I just don’t know which choice will let me focus on my goals without feeling like I’m falling behind in life.

It sounds like you're really focused on finding a balance between your financial stability, academic goals, and personal sense of independence. Could you help me understand more about what you hope to achieve in the next few years, and how each option might align with those goals?

Hey, yeah, I guess in the next few years I really want to finish up becoming a Psych NP and start building a career I’m proud of. I also wanna feel like I’m standing on my own two feet, but I’m not sure if moving out right now helps or hurts that with all the stress it’d bring.

It seems like you're striving for a future where you can confidently build your career as a Psych NP and feel financially independent, while also establishing a sense of self-reliance. Let's explore how each option might help or hinder your progress toward those goals, and see if we can identify which path might better support your aspirations.
Yeah, that sounds good. I’m just trying to figure out which way gives me the best shot at getting there without burning out or feeling like I’m letting myself down.

It sounds like you're weighing two paths that both carry potential risks and benefits, and you're trying to make a choice that aligns with your goals of becoming a Psych NP, feeling financially independent, and establishing self-reliance. Let's delve deeper into how each option might affect your progress toward these aspirations.
Yeah, I’m totally down to break it down more. I just wanna make sure I’m setting myself up for success without sacrificing too much along the way.

It's clear that you're committed to finding a path that aligns with your long-term goals while also being mindful of the potential challenges and trade-offs. Let's continue to explore how each option might impact your journey toward becoming a Psych NP, financial independence, and self-reliance, so we can better understand which direction might offer the most promising outcomes for you.
Cool, I appreciate digging into this with you. I just wanna get a clearer picture of how to balance chasing my dream of being a Psych NP with keeping my head above water, ya know?

It's great to see that you're dedicated to finding a path that aligns with your long-term goals while also being mindful of potential challenges and trade-offs. I'm here to help you explore each option and understand how they might impact your journey toward becoming a Psych NP, achieving financial independence, and establishing self-reliance.
Thanks for sticking with me on this. I’m just really torn between pushing forward with my dream and not losing myself in the process, if that makes sense.

I can see how important it is for you to pursue your dream of becoming a Psych NP while maintaining your sense of self and staying grounded. It's understandable to feel torn between these two important goals, and it's great that you're being mindful of the potential challenges and trade-offs involved.

Yeah, exactly, I just don’t wanna get so caught up in the grind that I forget who I am or what I’m even working toward. I guess I’m just trying to figure out how to keep that balance while still making real progress, ya know?

I hear you, and it's a really valid concern. It can be tough to keep your sense of self while working hard toward your goals, especially when it feels like a lot is on the line. It might be helpful to explore what that balance looks like for you and how you can incorporate self-care and reminders of your bigger picture into your daily life.

Totally, I think figuring out that balance is what’s tripping me up the most. Like, I wanna push hard for this Psych NP thing, but I also don’t wanna burn out or lose sight of why I started this in the first place, ya know?

That's a really important point to consider. It can be easy to lose sight of our motivations when we're in the thick of things. Maybe we can brainstorm some ways to remind yourself of your goals and values, even on the busiest of days?
Yeah, I’d really like that. I think having some kinda reminder or way to stay connected to my reasons for doing this would help me keep my head on straight, even when things get crazy.

I'm glad to hear that, and I'm here to help you explore those ideas. Let's start by identifying some specific strategies that might work for you, such as setting aside time for self-care, creating a visual reminder of your goals, or finding ways to incorporate your values into your daily routine. What do you think might be the most effective way for you to stay connected to your reasons and maintain your sense of self while working toward your dream of becoming a Psych NP?

Honestly, I think having a visual reminder, like maybe a little vision board or a sticky note on my desk with my big ‘why’ written on it, could really help me stay grounded. I’m also kinda into the idea of carving out some small time each day, even if it’s just 10 minutes, to chill and reflect on what I’m working toward, ya know?

That sounds like a great start. Having a visual reminder and setting aside time for reflection can help you stay connected to your 'why' and maintain balance. Let's explore how you can make these strategies work for you. What specific actions could you take to create your vision board or sticky note, and how might you incorporate your daily reflection time into your routine?

I think for the vision board, I could just grab some old magazines or print out pics that vibe with my goals, like images of mental health work or graduation, and pin ‘em up somewhere I see every day, like near my desk. For the reflection time, maybe I can set a reminder on my phone to take 10 minutes right after dinner to just sit quietly and think about what I did that day toward becoming a Psych NP, ya know?

It's great to see you've identified strategies that could help you stay grounded and connected to your goals. Creating a vision board and setting aside time for daily reflection can be powerful tools in maintaining balance and focus. Remember, you can always reach out to me for support as you work towards becoming a Psych NP.

Thanks, I really appreciate knowing I’ve got your support. It feels good to have a plan starting to come together. So, before we wrap up, do you have any quick tips on keeping this momentum going when things inevitably get hectic again?

Remember, it's all about consistency and adaptability. Keep your vision board and reflection time as non-negotiable parts of your routine, even if you have to adjust the timing or duration. Celebrate small victories along the way, and don't hesitate to reach out when you need support. You've got this!
Thanks, I’ll definitely try to keep those habits steady, even when life gets crazy. I like the idea of celebrating the small wins—think that’ll help keep me motivated.
